# [Bug]: fix tests structure so that users don't need to manually add init files

### Short description of current behavior

In the process of contributing new ML engines, @sammiller06 has suggested we add `__init__.py` files where needed to avoid `ModuleNotFoundError` errors, which I've confirmed are still happening as of #5454.

More context:

> ### PyTest’s classic ModuleNotFoundError
> I was unable to run the tests in unit/ml_handlers/ on first try as I got the classic “ModuleNotFoundError”. I know from Pytest experience that you need to add __init__.py files to specific subdirectories, but new contributors may find this a confusing blocker. 
Suggestion: make sure new contributors can run tests locally without adding their own __init__.py files



### Video or screenshots

_No response_

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### How to reproduce the error

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

Depending on what it is you're testing, it may also require additional dependencies: each DB handler or ML handler will have its own `requirements.txt` file that you should install prior to testing it. To address the issue described, you need to ensure that the `__init__.py` files are present in the appropriate directories so that Python treats them as packages. Here's an example of how you can add these files to the specified subdirectories:

```bash
touch unit/ml_handlers/__init__.py
```

You can run this command in your project's root directory to create an empty `__init__.py` file in the `unit/ml_handlers/` directory. This will make Python recognize `unit/ml_handlers/` as a package, and you should no longer encounter `ModuleNotFoundError` errors when running tests in that directory.

Repeat the same process for any other directories that require `__init__.py` files to be added to address similar import issues.

Hi @paxcema, I just try to address this issue to get the hang of contributing. It seems like the  file `pytest`  from command `python -m  pytest` is not there, and each subfolder  of ` ./test` already have the `.init` file, so do I miss something ?

Hey @nguyenbanhducA1K51, looking at the updated `staging` branch of the repo now and you're right. I will close this since it seems to have been solved, tests are being collected correctly now. 

Thanks anyway! I encourage you to look for other open issues.
